column4: Hello. I'm trying to restore a disk on another computer with dd, but I don't want the partition to get smaller.
you can always just dd from your backup file to your new partition, then ust gparted to fix whatever errors are gonna be introduced into your file system if the structure didn't perfectly match
did you dd /dev/sda or did you actually point it at a partition?
try doing your /dev/sda1 or whatever your partition is instead of the whole disk
also if you need to copy the mbr over, there are plenty of example on how to do that (so you can use yaboot) in the grub or lilo boot manager how to pages
thank you, but I'm trying to repair a PowerPC. :)

as i said before, when you point dd at the actual device not a partition, its going to copy everything to the new destination and if you HAD a partition table with a 40gb entry on it, it will be gone and you will now have an EXACT copy of your source device
hence why you always end up with a 8gb partition table on a 40gb hd
can you pastebin the output for "fdisk -l" ?
no it would not, as when you point DD to the DEVICE it will copy the DATA from exactly, starting with the 8gb partition table
what command are you using to copy from your flash install?
when I do that, it breaks Tiger from booting.
flash drives aren't supported on this model.
